key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal molecular and protein information with out-of-distribution (OOD) detection to produce per-sample uncertainty estimates, substantially improving binding-affinity predictions in polypharmacology settings.
problem_solved: Accurate prediction of compound–protein binding across many targets is hampered by distribution shifts and unreliable point estimates; the paper addresses how to detect OOD cases and provide calibrated, individual uncertainties so predictions can be trusted and prioritized.
method: Multimodal representation: jointly encode compound (e.g., graph/SMILES) and protein (sequence/structure) features to capture interaction mechanics.
OOD-aware uncertainty quantification: identify out-of-distribution examples and produce per-sample (individual) uncertainty scores rather than global variance estimates.
Integration for decision-making: use uncertainty to weigh or abstain from predictions, improving downstream hit prioritization in polypharmacology scenarios.
impact: Provides ML practitioners with a practical way to flag unreliable binding predictions and prioritize experiments, enabling safer and more efficient deployment of models in drug-discovery pipelines.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: multimodal encoders (molecule + protein) → interaction module → prediction + per-sample uncertainty
Scatter plot: predicted vs. measured affinity with error bars showing individual uncertainties and highlighted OOD points
Heatmap or network: compound × protein interaction matrix showing predicted affinities colored by uncertainty
Decision flowchart: uncertainty thresholding → prioritize/experiment/abstain actions
paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
